docs.lead_paragraph: The last time production workers at the Boeing Company went on strike, in 1989, the issue was too much work. Turning out airplanes at the rate of nearly one a day, they said they were exhausted by forced overtime and wanted some relief. Six years later, the people who assemble airplanes for the world's leading jet manufacturer are again on strike. But this time their concern is too little work, which they say has them fighting for their very survival.

headline.main: At Boeing, a War Over Job Exodus

docs.lead_paragraph: For decades, the mentally ill in the United States were shut away in psychiatric institutions and effectively barred from demanding better treatment, while parents -- often blamed by doctors for children's conditions -- were shamed into silence. No longer. In much the same way that members of minority groups, women and homosexuals have fought for and won civil rights protections and more government services, the mentally ill and their families have made similar breakthroughs, although their victories have been quieter, their growing power little noticed.

headline.main: Mentally Ill Gaining New Rights, With the Ill as Their Own Lobby

docs.snippet: For decades, the mentally ill in the United States were shut away in psychiatric institutions and effectively barred from demanding better treatment, while parents -- often blamed by doctors for children's conditions -- were shamed into silence.     ...

docs.lead_paragraph: International A3-10 FIGHTING IN NORTHERN BOSNIA While much of Bosnia remained calm on the first day of the latest cease-fire, fighting continued in the northwest, where Bosnian and Serb forces have been battling for strategic territory. A1 RUSSIAN GENERAL GAINS SUPPORT Aleksandr I. Lebed, a 45-year-old Afghan war hero who says the Russian empire must be restored, has emerged as a popular contender for the 1996 presidential elections. A1 GERMANY'S VIETNAMESE PARADOX A plan to deport some 40,000 Vietnamese exposes the paradox of Germany's attitude toward foreigners: Officials say they should be kept out to prevent violence, but this plays into the hands of the far right. A3 HAMAS MAY JOIN ELECTIONS The P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, said the militant Islamic group had decided to take part in planned elections in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, although this was not confirmed by Hamas itself. A5 PLAN TO LIMIT LAND MINES FAILS A U.N.-sponsored attempt to halt the spread of land mines foundered when China and other countries refused to accept restrictions on their manufacture and use. A6 The Ivory Coast's road to democracy takes a detour. A8 A volcano in the Philippines is said to damage Red Sea coral. A8 Montreal Journal: Living in a city of tense racial relations. A4 National A12-30 LEARNING FROM A DEFEAT The White House is using the same sort of tactics that were used against it on health care last year to fight Republican initiatives on Medicare and Medicaid. A1 A MESSAGE, AND THE MESSENGER Leaders of the march on Washington by black men rebuffed efforts by black officeholders and other political figures to endorse the demonstration but not its leader, Louis Farrakhan. A1 STORMS EXPOSE WEAKNESSES The abundance of tropical storms this year exposed continued weakness in Florida's building codes, population growth, disaster planning and insurance coverage. A12 FRAUD OPERATION IS BROKEN Federal officials said they had broken a fraud ring that stole more than $10 million in dozens of states, partly by recovering discarded checks, deposit slips and credit card receipts from the trash. A12 F.A.A. ACTS ON BAD PARTS The Federal Aviation Administration announced a plan to crack down on the use of aircraft parts that are counterfeit, bootleg, defective, deliberately mislabeled or otherwise not approved. A17 SIZING UP THE '96 FIELD Voters in Easton, Pa., as elsewhere, are beginning to look at the candidates vying for the Presidency, and many are not enthusiastic. A18 A NEW NAVY EMBARRASSMENT As the Navy tries to put the 1991 Tailhook sexual harassment scandal behind it, a new embarrassment has emerged: 3 of the 27 captains selected to become admirals have been accused of misconduct. A25 BOLSTERING BLOOD SAFETY The Government said a top official would oversee the safety of the nation's blood supplies to help prevent the disastrous spread of another dangerous infectious agent like H.I.V., the AIDS virus. A26 CONFRONTING DOMESTIC VIOLENCE In death, Nicole Brown Simpson has invested the American psyche with the conviction that domestic violence is a problem that must be dealt with, experts say. A28 Metro Digest B1 BILL PASSED ON POLICE The New York State Senate passed and sent to the Governor a bill that would effectively unravel one of Mayor Giuliani's proudest accomplishments: the merger of the housing and transit police forces into the city Police Department. A1 THE COLD WAR IN EDUCATION Ten days ago, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver announced he would hold an "education summit," evoking images of Cold War conferences where enemies met to work toward peace. The summit showed that, in Albany, the Cold War is still on. A1 CHARGES IN ABUSING DETAINEES Six Union County, N.J., corrections officers were arrested and charged with beating and taunting illegal immigrants brought to their jail after a riot in June at a privately run detention center. A1 Business Digest D1 Weekend C1-34 Art: Rembrandt show. C1 Art in Review C23 Two Picasso shows. C28 "Temporarily Possessed." C30 The International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show. B9 Mariners turn to Johnson. B9 Braves are outplaying Reds. B10 Columns: Anderson on Steinbrenner B9 Robert Lipsyte B11 Tennis: Germans are transfixed by Graf's tax troubles. B9 Obituaries B7 Peter R. Wisher, coach who created a dance genre for the deaf. Editorials/Op-Ed A32-33 Editorials Albany's gift to the police union. Cloistered Japanese banks. A Nobel with political punch. Shortchanging death row. Letters A. M. Rosenthal: Upwardly mobile bigotry. Bob Herbert: In deep denial. Anthony Lewis: Racist chic. Melvin Konner: A giant leap backward. docs.lead_paragraph: As Republicans claimed solidarity on their 1996 budget -- and worked feverishly in private to maintain it -- two House committees gave them a symbolic lift Wednesday and early today, voting to send a disputed overhaul of Medicare to the House floor for debate next week. The House Commerce Committee approved the overhaul early today, and the House Ways and Means Committee approved it on Wednesday.

headline.main: Medicare Overhaul Bill Is Sent to the House Floor

docs.snippet: As Republicans claimed solidarity on their 1996 budget -- and worked feverishly in private to maintain it -- two House committees gave them a symbolic lift Wednesday and early today, voting to send a disputed overhaul of Medicare to the House floor...

docs.lead_paragraph: JUDITH S. KAYE, the Chief Judge of the State of New York, is to participate this afternoon in a symposium called "Confronting Breast Cancer in the 90's" at Fordham University Law School. She and three other judges plan to grill six health-care experts, including Dr. Susan J. Blumenthal, an Assistant Surgeon General, along with an official of Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield and a lawyer who specializes in suits involving breast cancer. . "I'm going to ask questions like how does the indigent woman get state-of-the-art medicine?" Judge Kaye said yesterday. "What are we going to do with our genetic information? We know so much at birth about a genetic destiny, and how does that affect employment, insurance and issues like that?"

docs.lead_paragraph: Most mothers and babies need to stay in the hospital at least 48 hours after childbirth, the nation's largest group of pediatricians said today, bucking a trend toward shorter stays that save money. "The fact that a short hospital stay can be accomplished does not mean it is appropriate for every mother and infant," the American Academy of Pediatrics said in a policy statement.

headline.main: Longer Hospital Stays for Childbirth Are Needed, Pediatricians Say

docs.lead_paragraph: More than two-thirds of Americans suffering from heart disease fail to enroll in cardiac rehabilitation programs that could improve the length and quality of their lives, an expert panel said today. The group, convened by the Government to examine the use of supervised heart rehabilitation programs, said doctors and patients should be made more aware of the programs' benefits and should demand that such services be widely available.

headline.main: Many Heart Patients Failing to Seize a Lifeline

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials say New York City must be more specific about how it will protect the needs of people with H.I.V. or AIDS before the Government will approve the city's request to make managed care mandatory for most Medicaid recipients. Officials at the Health Care Financing Administration, which is considering the city's application, said last week that the agency was not ready to act on the request. A decision is expected by Oct. 31.

headline.main: U.S. Wants AIDS Care Detailed in H.M.O. Shift
